abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Economic Recovery Credit
            (EERC) for the Comoros had a satisfactory outcome, unlikely
            sustainability, moderate institutional development impact,
            and satisfactory performance by both Bank and Borrower.  The
            EERC was designed as a one-off operation, and no follow-up
            of this type is planned.  The major factor affecting
            implementation was ongoing political instability and
            disagreements between the central and island governments.
            Lessons learned concerning the ICR process: 1. The standard
            ICR format may not be best suited to an emergency project.
            2. In the changeable context, the process of generating and
            drafting the ICR has been as valuable as the final report.
            Lessons for Comoros: 1. There remains no shared
            understanding of what the political transition out of the
            crisis and national reconciliation mean in practice.  2.
            Service delivery and infrastructure investments can be
            carried out effectively if the credit implementation and
            governance meet the highest level of standards. 3. Improved
            communications between development agents on the different
            islands of the country are needed.  Lessons for the Bank: 1)
            This kind of credit involves a number of trade-offs,
            promising high gain but is entered at high risk. 2) The
            relationship between the Bank's operations and the
            Bank's country strategy needs to be continuously
            monitored and evaluated. 3) An instrument is needed allowing
            rapid and flexible disbursement of funds, while maintaining
            some control over the way the funds are spent.  4) Where a
            credit is linked to an emergency recovery program, it is
            important that it is made explicit how and to what extent
            the activities are expected to contribute to the overall
            objective and that suitable indicators and procedures are
            defined. 5) A complex and flexible project carried out in a
            volatile political environment requires regular supervision
            and attention, coming at a heavy price in variable costs to
            the Bank.
